Intro.Title: You can have a direct impact on the future of men with prostate cancer
Intro.Text: The Metastatic Prostate Cancer Project is a nationwide genomic research study for men with advanced or metastatic prostate cancer. We seek to generate the most comprehensive database that will be shared with the entire research community to accelerate discoveries.

FirstBlock.Text: We can only accomplish this by working directly with men like you, men who are willing to anonymously share their tissues and medical information.

FirstStep.Title: Step 1
FirstStep.Subtitle: Tell us about yourself
FirstStep.TextPt2: and complete a short online form to tell us about yourself and your prostate cancer.

SecondStep.Title: Step 2
SecondStep.Subtitle: Give us permission to collect your samples and data
SecondStep.Text: You will be directed to an online consent form to get your permission to collect your samples and data. We will send you a saliva kit and a blood kit. We will do the rest--we’ll contact your doctors and hospitals to securely obtain copies of your medical records and a portion of your stored tumor samples.

ThirdStep.Title: Step 3
ThirdStep.Subtitle: Learn with us along the way
ThirdStep.Text: As we learn, we will provide you with regular updates and share any discoveries coming out of the project. We also may ask you additional questions about your experience to help with future studies.

ThirdBlock.Text: We are asking you to say "Count Me In" and give something invaluable to prostate cancer research. Your samples and medical information will be used for transformative genomic studies that will ultimately lead to a better understanding and faster advances in the treatment of prostate cancer.

FifthBlock.Text: With your help, patients can be the driving force behind cancer research.

DataRelease.Title: MPCproject Data

MainText.Section1: The MPCproject has released publicly available datasets in cBioPortal. This data is being released as it is generated, and as the project continues to enroll patients, more data will be added regularly.
MainText.Section2: We have focused our efforts on generating and releasing this data so that the entire research community can have access to it. As we generate and share more data over time, we anticipate that this will accelerate discoveries in metastatic and advanced prostate cancer.
MainText.Section3: To everybody who is taking part in the MPCproject, we would like to extend our most sincere gratitude for your partnership that enables the creation of this data.

InformationList.Title: Below, you will find the following information:
InformationList.Item3: List of common terms used in this research
InformationList.Item4: Link to the methods used to generate this data
InformationList.Text: Questions about these data, including how to cite, can be directed to

BioPortal.Title: The MPCproject Data on cBioPortal
BioPortal.Link: Visit cBioPortal to explore the MPCproject data

DataRelease.AdditionalInfoTitle: Additional Information about the Genomic Data

Goal.Title: What is the goal of this data release?
Goal.Text: The goal of this public data release is to share clinical, genomic, molecular, and patient-reported data on metastatic and advanced prostate cancer to accelerate discoveries and the development of new treatment strategies for metastatic and advanced prostate cancer. Our goal is to add new data to the collection as it is generated.

Difference.Title: What makes this data different from what is found in existing studies?
Difference.Text: The collection of data in this release is different for several reasons:

ReasonsList.Item1: All of the data has been generated through direct partnership with patients
ReasonsList.Item2: The MPCproject data combines genomic, clinical, and patient-reported data all in one place from metastatic and advanced prostate cancer patients
ReasonsList.Item3: Data is shared with the entire research community as soon as it is analyzed (e.g. pre-publication)

Item4.SubItem2: Treatment data, including all reported drugs given in the metastatic and/or advanced setting and the duration of that therapy
Item4.SubItem3: Patient-reported data from the MPCproject enrollment survey

Item5.SubItem1: Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) on a sample with the sample’s pathology data
Item5.SubItem2: Tumor fraction value derived from Ultra Low Pass Whole Genome Sequencing (ULP-WGS) performed on cell-free DNA (cfDNA) from blood samples

Additional.Title: Will the MPCproject generate and release additional data?
Additional.Text: Yes, the MPCproject is an ongoing research initiative. The project will continue to enroll patients and request saliva, blood, and tissue samples indefinitely. Our goal is to release data as it is generated.

DataIncluded.Title: What data elements are included?
DataIncluded.Text: Data is included for the following categories:

Item1.Title: Genomic Information
Item1.Text: Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) information is included for tumor samples, including mutations, small insertions/deletions, amplifications, and deletions.

Item2.Title: Medical Record (MedR): All information that was derived from a medical record is denoted with the prefix MedR
Item2.Text: Information about diagnosis and treatment was abstracted from patients’ medical records.

Item3.Title: Pathology Report (PATH): All information regarding pathology is denoted with the prefix PATH
Item3.Text: Detailed histologic information about each sample was abstracted from pathology reports associated with each sample.

Item4.Title: Patient-reported (PRD): All patient-reported data elements are denoted with the prefix PRD
Item4.Text: Every patient that registered for the study had the option of completing a 17-question survey about their experiences with metastatic and/or advanced prostate cancer. Twelve questions from this survey have been abstracted for inclusion. These responses have been modified and formatted to prevent individual identification without altering scientific utility.

Resources.Title: Are there resources to define the terminology used in this data release?
Resources.TextPt2: page is The National Cancer Institute’s comprehensive dictionary of clinical terms, as well as definitions of some common genomic terms.

Cite.Title: How should this data be cited?
Cite.TextPt1: We encourage use of this data for your research studies and publications. To help us track data usage, we kindly ask that you send us an email at
Cite.TextPt2: to let us know whenever you have published or presented work using or referencing this dataset. We also request that you please include the following attribution: "The results included here include the use of data from The Metastatic Prostate Cancer Project (https://mpcproject.org/), a project of Count Me In (https://joincountmein.org/)."

Unknown.Title: Why are some attributes “Unknown” for some cases and not for others?
Unknown.Text: All of the clinical information that is gathered comes directly from medical records or pathology reports. If the complete report or record that was received did not explicitly contain the information, the field was marked as “Unknown” in order to ensure accuracy.

Sequence.Title: Will everyone who registers for this study have their tumor sequenced?
Sequence.Text: As of December 2019, over 910 men with metastatic and/or advanced prostate cancer have registered for the project. Of these registrants, over 700 have provided consent. Approximately 500 patients have sent in saliva samples and over 350 patients have sent in blood samples. Medical records and tumor samples are being requested for everyone who has sent in saliva and/or blood and who lives in the USA or Canada. Obtaining medical records and tissue samples is a manual process involving faxes, phone calls, and additional follow up. The ultimate goal is to obtain medical records and tumors from as many consenting patients as possible.

Inform.Title: Can I use this data to inform my clinical care?
Inform.Text: This data is intended to be used for research purposes only. Genomic data included in this study is generated in a research lab, not in a clinical lab. All annotations have been de-identified. Therefore, this data cannot be used to inform clinical decision-making. Some of the data has been intentionally altered to protect confidentiality in a way that does not affect data integrity (for example, Age at Diagnosis has been grouped).

Item1.Text: Detailed methods for how these data were generated and analyzed.

Item3.Text: Forms documenting informed consent and contact information.

Item5.Text: Included in each blood sample kit.

Glossary.Title: Glossary
Glossary.Text: For reference to common terms used in cancer care and research use the National Cancer Institute Dictionary of Cancer Terms

Additional.TextPt1: If there are additional terms that you would like defined that are not included in the National Cancer Institute Dictionary, please send an email to
Additional.TextPt2: and include “New Glossary Term” in your email subject line. We will be creating a glossary to define some of the genomics terms seen on cBioPortal.

PageHeader.Part1: The Metastatic Prostate Cancer Project is part of
PageHeader.Part2: a nonprofit organization that brings together patients and researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research.

Section1.Part1: is stewarded by four leading organizations: Emerson Collective, a California-based social change organization; the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, a leading nonprofit biomedical research institution; the Biden Cancer Initiative, an independent nonprofit organization that builds on the federal government’s Cancer Moonshot; and the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, a leading cancer hospital. For more information about

Section2.Part1: The Metastatic Prostate Cancer Project is led by
Section2.Part3: MD, an oncologist and prostate cancer researcher and directed by Corrie Painter, PhD, a cancer researcher, cancer patient and patient advocate. This project was designed and has been implemented collaboratively with metastatic prostate cancer patients, patient advocates, cancer researchers, physicians, and clinical specialists. We leverage the power of
Section2.Part5: resources and the voice of the metastatic prostate cancer community in order to focus cutting edge genomic science squarely on people living with metastatic prostate cancer.

MoreDetails.Title: Learn more about the Metastatic Prostate Cancer Project

MainText.Pt1: The Metastatic Prostate Cancer Project takes a new approach to cancer research in which researchers partner directly with men with metastatic and/or advanced prostate cancer, who share their samples and clinical information in order to speed up important discoveries. The project is part of
MainText.Pt2: a nonprofit organization that brings together patients and researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research.
MainText.Pt3: is stewarded by four leading organizations: Emerson Collective, a California-based social change organization; the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, a leading nonprofit biomedical research institution; the Biden Cancer Initiative, an independent nonprofit organization that builds on the federal government’s Cancer Moonshot; and the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, a leading cancer hospital. Our goal is to reach out to men with metastatic and/or advanced prostate cancer around the country in order to study their cancer using cutting-edge genomic and molecular research studies performed at the Broad Institute by allowing men to participate in these studies regardless of where they live.

AboutYourself.Title: A. Tell us about yourself.
AboutYourself.Text: Click "Count Me In" and complete a simple online form to tell us about yourself and your cancer. Our goal is to perform genomics studies that will enable us to understand the genomic underpinnings of this disease. In order to understand this disease, we need to hear about your experiences with prostate cancer and couple that information with what we learn from the DNA in your tumor.

Permission.Title: B. Give us permission to collect your samples and data.
Permission.Text: After you fill out the initial survey, we will ask you to fill out an online consent form that requests your permission to obtain copies of your medical records and some of your stored tumor tissue. We’ll also ask you to tell us where you received your medical care so we can contact your doctors and hospitals.

Request.Title: C. We’ll find and request your records and tissue.
Request.Text: Our team will contact your doctors and hospitals to obtain copies of your medical records and a portion of your stored tumor samples. We will ask pathology departments to share only a part of the tumor tissue, and not to share anything with us that might be needed for clinical care.

SendUs.Title: D. Provide us with a saliva and/or blood sample.
SendUs.Text: We’ll also send you a simple kit to collect a saliva sample, which will contain "healthy" DNA that can be compared with DNA from your tumor sample. We may also send you a simple kit to collect a blood sample. We ask that you bring in a blood tube to your health care providers office and ask them to draw a sample, which may contain DNA from your tumor. This may help us to understand the genomics of your cancer from a simple blood draw.

Analyze.Title: E. We’ll analyze your tumor and medical data.
Analyze.Text: We will perform cutting-edge, comprehensive genomic analyses on your tumor and saliva sample. Sequencing data we generate will be securely stored in a protected database at the Broad Institute along with information from your medical record. Any information that would make it easy to identify you as an individual will be removed from all genomic and clinical data.

Share.Title: F. We’ll share the data with other researchers.
Share.Text: Once potentially identifying information has been removed, our database of genomic and medical information (with your identifying information removed) will be shared with the National Institutes of Health and the cancer research community, and will be able to be used for other genomic and molecular studies to help understand prostate cancer and develop new therapies.

Learn.Title: G. Learn with us along the way.
Learn.Text: Throughout the project, we will provide all patients who say "Count Me In" with regular updates about the status of the project and information about new studies that we are conducting. We will also share any discoveries from these research projects with you. We also may ask you additional questions about your experience to help with future studies — we want to hear what’s important to you.

Goal.Question: 1. What is the goal of this project?
Goal.Section1: This project will connect men with metastatic and/or advanced prostate cancer across the country with scientists using cutting-edge technology to study cancer's genetic and molecular causes. Cancer is not a single disease, and each tumor holds part of the puzzle. While prostate cancer is very common, few men have the ability to contribute their tumor samples and clinical data to cancer research, largely because they do not have a way of doing so.
Goal.Section2: We believe everyone should have the opportunity to contribute to research, especially now that the combination of genome sequencing and internet-based communication has made it easier to give people that opportunity.

Research.Question: 2. Who is conducting this research?
Research.Text2: a nonprofit organization that brings together patients & researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research.
Research.Text3: is stewarded by four leading organizations: Emerson Collective, a California-based social change organization; the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, a leading nonprofit biomedical research institution; the Biden Cancer Initiative, an independent nonprofit organization that builds on the federal government’s Cancer Moonshot; and the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, a leading cancer hospital, The MPCproject also works with a growing coalition of non-profit advocacy partners. Our team — led by Dr. Eliezer Van Allen, prostate cancer physician and researcher— is made up of cancer researchers, physicians, clinical specialists, and patient advocates. Learn more

Involved.Question: 3. How have patients been involved in the design of this project?
Involved.Section1: We have worked closely with men with prostate cancer from the beginning of this project through its design and implementation. Patients have been involved in all aspects including concept, goals, messaging, forms, and even the design of this website.
Involved.Section2: We're proud to have as our Advocacy Partners: Prostate Cancer Foundation, Prostate Cancer International, ADK Hike for Hope, Cancer ABCs, Us Too, AnCan, Malecare, Prostate Network, Patient Power, Blue Cure, The Men’s Cancer Network, Veterans Prostate Cancer Awareness, Fans for the Cure, FORCE, and Hampton Roads Prostate Health Forum.

Costs.Question: 4. Are there any costs for me to participate?
Costs.Section1: No, there are no costs to you.

Share.Question: 5. After I provide my information, will I be asked to share my tumor tissue and medical records?
Share.Section1: As part of the process of providing consent, we will ask your permission to share your stored tumor tissue. We will keep you informed about our progress along the way.

UsedUp.Question: 6. If I am asked to share a tissue sample, will my tissue be used up?
UsedUp.Section1: We will take every measure to ensure that your samples are not used up as a result of these studies. We will ask the pathologists who have access to your stored tumor samples to make sure that they share only a small portion with us. If there doesn’t appear to be enough to allow for future clinical testing, we will not request for your samples to be sent to us, and we will notify you that we did not use your samples for this reason.

Analyzed.Question: 7. If my tissue and medical records are analyzed, will I receive any information back from this study?
Analyzed.Section1: Because our sequencing tests are performed in a research lab and not a clinical lab, we are not currently permitted to return personal genetic data to you. However, we will regularly update you with key discoveries that we make about this disease, overall results, and progress made through this research.

Profit.Question: 8. Is this research being conducted for profit?
Profit.Section1: No. This project is a not-for-profit, academic research endeavor. Our mission is to generate data to freely share in a way that protects your personal information with the research community in order to fuel scientific discoveries.

Info.Question: 9. Is there information that I can bring to my doctor so that I can discuss this study with them?
Info.Text: Yes, you can print out or use your mobile device to share the document linked here:

Section1.Text: You can access a 1 page printable information sheet about the project linked here:

Section2.TextPt1: If you have any other questions, please email us at

Disclaimer.Title: View MPCproject Data
Disclaimer.Text: You are now leaving the MPCproject website and will be directed to cBioPortal. Please note that as these data were generated by the MPCproject in a research, not a clinical, laboratory, they are for research purposes only and cannot be used to inform clinical decision-making.

SessionWillExpire.Title: Your session will time-out soon
SessionWillExpire.Text: To protect your privacy, the system is going to log you out because you have been away for a while. Click “Continue” to stay logged in. Click “Sign Out” if you are done for now.

Warning.Title: Download Chrome or Safari to Continue
Warning.Text1: This project is designed for use with the internet's safest and most popular browsers -- Chrome and Safari.
Warning.Text2: It looks like you are using Internet Explorer. You will need to use another browser in order to join the project. We suggest you use Chrome or Safari to ensure that your experience with the website is smooth and secure.

Text3.Pt1: Click the following links to download
Text3.Pt3: Chrome and Safari are always free.

InternationalPatients.Title: Information for International Patients

ThankYou.TextPt1: Thank you for your interest in joining the Metastatic Prostate Cancer Project. Currently, the Metastatic Prostate Cancer Project is open to patients in the United States or Canada. From the Country field on your survey, it appears that you do not live in the United States or Canada. If you do live or are treated in the United States or Canada, please reach out to us at

InternationalPatients.Understand: We understand that the experiences of every patient matters, and eventually want to extend these studies internationally. Understanding where people are registering from may enable us to better understand what parts of the world might be most interested in participating in the future of Count Me In projects.
